resources.string: User Manual
• Turn on the solar-powered power supply to activate the hardware components.

• Use the Logitech Extreme 3D Pro joystick to control the collective movement of the helicopter rotor assembly.\n\n • Push the joystick forward, backward, left, or right to maneuver the rotor assembly accordingly.
• Rotate the potentiometer knob to adjust the speed of the stepper motor.\n\n • Turn the knob clockwise to increase speed and counterclockwise to decrease speed.

• Ensure that the power supply is turned on and properly connected.

 • Check the connections between the servo motors, stepper motor, and Arduino Mega controller.

 • Verify that the Arduino Mega is powered on and functioning correctly.

 • If hardware components are damaged or malfunctioning, spare parts for each component will be provided for replacement.

• If the stepper motor speed is not adjusting as expected:

 		 -Check the wiring connections between the potentiometer and the Arduino Mega.

 • Ensure that the potentiometer is functioning properly by testing with a multimeter.

 • Adjust the code in the Arduino Mega to calibrate the speed control.

 • If the stepper motor itself is faulty, spare stepper motor components will be provided for replacement.

If the servo motors are not responding to joystick inputs:

 		 • Confirm that the Logitech Extreme 3D Pro joystick is connected securely to the Arduino Mega.

 		 • Check the code in the Arduino Mega to ensure proper mapping of joystick inputs to servo motor control.

 		 • Verify that the servo motors are receiving power and are connected correctly to the Arduino Mega.

 		 • If the servo motors are damaged or malfunctioning, spare servo motor components will be provided for replacement.

If troubleshooting does not resolve the issue, try resetting the Arduino Mega:

 		 • Locate the reset button on the Arduino Mega board.

 		 • Press the reset button to restart the microcontroller and reset any potential software issues.

 		 • After resetting, check if the hardware components respond as expected.

 		 • If the Arduino Mega itself is damaged or malfunctioning, spare Arduino Mega boards will be provided for replacement.

If issues persist, refer to the project documentation or seek assistance from a knowledgeable individual with experience in Arduino programming and hardware troubleshooting. Spare parts will be available upon request for replacement of damaged or malfunctioning components.\n\n

• 4 MG996R Servo Motors: Responsible for collective movement.

 • NEMA 17 Stepper Motor: Controls the throttle.

 • Arduino Mega: Main controller board for the system.

 • Potentiometer: Used to control the speed of the stepper motor.

 • Logitech Extreme 3D Pro: Controller for collective movements.

 • Solar-Powered Power Supply: Provides power to the entire system.

 • 3D Printed Parts: Includes rotor blades, swashplates, and other structural components.

• Description: The MG996R is a high-torque servo motor commonly used in robotics and mechanical applications.

 		• Function: Responsible for controlling the collective movement of the helicopter rotor blades, allowing for precise adjustments in pitch.

 		• Key Features:

 				• High torque output

 				• Metal gears for durability

 				• Wide operating voltage range

• Description: A type of stepper motor widely used in 3D printers, CNC machines, and other applications requiring precise control of movement.

 		• Function: Controls the throttle of the rotor assembly, regulating the speed of the rotor blades.

 		• Key Features:

 				• High precision and control

 				• Robust and reliable performance

 				• Multiple step angles for detailed movement

• Description: A microcontroller board based on the ATmega2560, offering extensive I/O capabilities.

 		• Function: Acts as the main controller for the system, processing inputs from the potentiometer and the Logitech controller to manage the servo and stepper motors.

 		• Key Features:

 				• 54 digital I/O pins

 				• 16 analog inputs

 				• Large memory capacity for complex programs

• Description: An adjustable resistor used to control electrical devices.

 		• Function: Used to adjust the speed of the NEMA 17 stepper motor by varying resistance and providing input to the Arduino Mega.

 		• Key Features:

 				• Smooth rotation for precise control

 				• Durable construction

 				• Easy to integrate with microcontrollers

• Description: A joystick controller designed for gaming and simulation applications.

 		• Function: Provides input for controlling the collective movements of the rotor blades, allowing users to simulate real-life helicopter maneuvers.

 		• Key Features:

 				• 12 programmable buttons

 				• High-precision joystick

 				• Comfortable and ergonomic design

• Description: A power supply unit that converts solar energy into electrical energy to power the system.

 		• Function: Provides renewable and sustainable power to the entire rotor assembly model.

 		• Key Features:

 				• Environmentally friendly energy source

 				• Reliable power output

 				• Reduces dependency on traditional power sources

• Swashplate 

 				• Description: A critical part of the rotor system that connects to the rotor blades.

 				• Function: Allows for the transfer of control inputs from the servos to the rotor blades.


 		• Lower Swashplate

 				• Description: Works in conjunction with the upper swashplate to control the blade pitch.

 				• Function: Ensures coordinated movement of the rotor blades.


 		• Blade Grip

 				• Description: Holds the rotor blades securely.

 				• Function: Ensures stable attachment of the rotor blades to the assembly.


 		• Rotor Blades

 				• Description: Main aerodynamic surfaces that generate lift.

 				• Function: Provide the necessary lift and thrust for the rotor assembly.


 		• Ball Joint

 				• Description: A spherical bearing allowing for multi-directional movement.

 				• Function: Facilitates smooth movement of control surfaces.


 		• Rotor Mast

 				• Description: The central shaft of the rotor system.

 				• Function: Supports the rotor blades and transmits rotational force.


 		• Base

 				• Description: The foundation of the rotor assembly model.

 				• Function: Provides stability and support to the entire structure.


 		• Servo Base

 				• Description: Mounting platform for servo motors.

 				• Function: Secures the servos in place for optimal performance.
